summary: Update Screen Scraper with AI and Puppeteer to Collect Pricing Data Since Major Changes to the Bedrock Pricing Dynamic HTML
description:
Value Statement
 * As a ML Engineer who calculates model invocation costs per 1000 input/output tokens from the Bedrock pricing web page, I need the ability to track Bedrock invocation costs from real-time/current model token pricing data so that I get accurate cost tracking and reporting to discern if users are over budget.

Acceptance Criteria
 * Develop and deploy a container running Node.js and Puppeteer to filter the dynamic HTML on 'AWS GovCloud'
 * Scrape the pricing data into the schema:

{code:java}
{
    "model_family": "Anthropic",
    "model_name": "Claude Sonnet 4",
    "price_per_1000_input_tokens": 0.003,
    "price_per_1000_output_tokens": 0.015
  }{code}
 * Version controlled pricing and model ID data is inserted into the PostgreSQL database from the Python API.
 * Documentation is updated here: Comments in Python code and high-level overview in README markdown document in the Git repository.
 * Automated or manual tests were added here: Automated integration tests.

Assumptions
None

Dependencies
 * None

Notes
 * Per our conversations with the client, the following information may be useful: The tenants will start using Bedrock model families other than Anthropic, including but limited to Meta Llama models.

Out of Scope
N/A

summary: Create example Figma MCP to run locally
description:
As an MLE, I want to create a proof of concept example of using Figma MCP locally.

AC: Repo created with Figma starter file, notebook, and basic front end that can interact with Copilot.

summary: Develop List All Resources Function for Crossplane Claimer to Enhance Resource Visibility
description:
Value Statement As a BIP-AI Infrastructure Engineer, I need a function in the crossplane claimer that lists all Crossplane resources in a cluster, so that I can have comprehensive visibility into resource states and ownership for better infrastructure management.

Description The crossplane claimer currently has limited resource listing capabilities. This story involves developing or enhancing functionality to retrieve and display all Crossplane resources in a cluster with detailed metadata, improving operational visibility and supporting debugging workflows.

Acceptance Criteria When I evaluate the implementation approach, then I need to: Analyze existing list paused resources function for reusability Review the current 5-minute query function for potential extension Determine whether to modify existing function or create new function based on code duplication assessment Document recommended approach with justification When I implement the list all resources function, then it needs to: Return a dictionary of all Crossplane resources in the cluster Include resource name, ownership references, annotations, labels, plurals, apiVersion, and kind for each resource Support manual refresh capability from the front-end interface Handle cluster authentication and permissions appropriately When I test the function locally, then it needs to: Successfully retrieve and format resource data Handle edge cases like missing annotations or labels gracefully Provide consistent response structure across different resource types Execute within acceptable performance parameters When I test the function in SBX environment, then it needs to: Work with actual cluster configuration and permissions Return accurate data for real Crossplane resources Integrate properly with existing claimer functionality Maintain system stability during execution Definition of Done Implementation approach evaluated and documented Function developed and tested locally Function validated in SBX environment Code follows existing claimer patterns and standards Documentation updated with new function usage

summary: Prototype Bedrock Crossplane Providers to Enable Agent Provisioning
description:
Title: Implement BIP-AI RBAC for tooling ArgoCD to allow management of applications

Value Statement As a BIP-AI Infrastructure Engineer, I need to implement RBAC (Role-Based Access Control) for tooling ArgoCD, so that I can enable proper access management and security controls for application deployment and management within the BIP-AI platform. Description This story involves implementing comprehensive RBAC policies for the tooling ArgoCD instance to ensure proper access control, security boundaries, and operational governance for application management for BIP AI Infrastructure engineers. The implementation will follow security best practices and integrate with existing authentication and authorization systems.

A/C: When I implement RBAC policies for tooling ArgoCD, then I need to: Define appropriate roles and permissions for different user types (developers, operators, administrators) Configure RBAC policies that align with BIP-AI security requirements Implement proper access controls for application management operations Follow existing RBAC patterns and conventions used in the BIP platform When I configure the RBAC integration, then it needs to: Integrate with existing authentication systems (OIDC, SSO) Support fine-grained permissions for different environments (dev, staging, prod) Enable proper application lifecycle management controls Restrict access based on user roles and project boundaries When I test the RBAC implementation, then it needs to: Successfully authenticate and authorize users based on their roles Properly enforce permission boundaries for application operations Handle different user scenarios (create, read, update, delete applications) Work correctly in ephemeral environment for validation When I validate the RBAC functionality, then it needs to: Demonstrate proper access control enforcement Show correct permission inheritance and role mapping Handle edge cases and unauthorized access attempts appropriately Maintain audit trails for access and operations Definition of Done: RBAC policies implemented and configured for tooling ArgoCD Integration with authentication systems completed Comprehensive testing performed in ephemeral environment PR created with approvals from Engineering team Documentation updated with RBAC configuration and usage patterns

summary: Build Comprehensive Grafana Dashboard
description:
Title:
Develop a Lambda Function to Parse Bedrock CloudWatch Logs and Write Bedrock Model Metrics to Prometheus.
Value Statement:
As an MLOps Engineer, I need to develop a Lambda function to parse Bedrock CloudWatch logs and push the data to Prometheus. A Grafana dashboard will read these metrics from Prometheus and visualize the data so that stakeholders and decision makers have timely and accurate usage data. This data will serve to view recent and historical model usage, offering full transparency and predictability.
Acceptance Criteria:
* Draw an architectural diagram that includes CloudWatch, Lambda function, Prometheus, and Grafana.
* An IAM role is created for the Lambda function.
* The role has logs:GetLogEvents and logs:FilterLogEvents permissions scoped to the specific Bedrock CloudWatch Log Group.
* The role has network permissions to access the EKS cluster and the Prometheus Push Gateway endpoint within the GovCloud VPC.
* The role has prometheus:PushMetrics or equivalent permissions to the Push Gateway.
* The Lambda function is triggered by new log entries in the Bedrock CloudWatch Log Group.
* The function parses the logs to extract identified metrics.
* (Stretch goal) The function retrieves the cost per model (and potentially per 1000 input/output tokens).
Saumil Dave's avatar
Saumil Dave

2 days ago

5
John Bonfardeci's avatar
John Bonfardeci

a day ago

Title:
Build Comprehensive Grafana Dashboard
Value Statement:
* As a MLOps Engineer, I need to create a detailed Grafana dashboard, so that we can visualize Bedrock usage, performance, and cost metrics from Prometheus.
Acceptance Criteria:
* Grafana is connected to the Prometheus data source.
* A new "Bedrock Performance and Cost" dashboard is created.
* The dashboard includes visualizations for:
    * Total invocation count (filterable by model and application).
    * Total cost (filterable by model and application).
    * Average tokens per invocation (input and output).
    * Cost per model over time.
    * Invocation trends over time.
* The dashboard is shared with the team and stakeholders.

summary: Resolve MLKit dependency conflicts with SageMaker prebuilt containers to ensure consistent deployment
description:
Title
Resolve MLKit dependency conflicts with SageMaker prebuilt containers to ensure consistent deployment.

Value Statement
As a BIP AI Tenant who uses the MLKit Python package for development and deployment in SageMaker Studio, I need the ability to ensure consistent dependencies between development and SageMaker prebuilt containers so that I can avoid compatibility issues and streamline the deployment process.

Acceptance Criteria
When tenants use the MLKit Python package in SageMaker Studio, they have clear guidance on resolving dependency conflicts with SageMaker prebuilt containers.
Documentation is updated in the tenant resources deployment and training notebooks to reflect the strategy for managing dependencies.
If necessary, dependency restrictions within the MLKit Python package are eased to improve compatibility with SageMaker prebuilt containers.
Validation:

Verify that the updated documentation provides clear steps for resolving dependency conflicts.
Confirm that tenants can successfully use the MLKit Python package with SageMaker prebuilt containers (e.g., scikit-learn) without dependency issues.
Test the updated MLKit package (if modified) to ensure compatibility with both development and deployment environments.

summary: Leverage copilot to create mlkit API reference
description:
Title
Leverage Copilot to create MLKit API reference and deploy it in the MLKit repository.

Value Statement
As a BIP AI Tenant who uses the MLKit Python package, I need the ability to access a comprehensive API reference so that I can understand and utilize MLKit's functionality effectively in my workflows.

Acceptance Criteria
When the API reference is created, it includes all key MLKit functions, classes, and usage examples.
The API reference is generated using Copilot and reviewed for accuracy and completeness.
The API reference is deployed in the MLKit repository for easy access and version control (e.g., as a docs/ folder or markdown file).
Validation:

Verify that the API reference includes all relevant MLKit functionality with clear descriptions and examples.
Confirm that the API reference is accessible in the MLKit repository.
Ensure that tenants can use the API reference to understand and implement MLKit features.

 

 

Repo for this project is located at https://github.com/department-of-veterans-affairs/bip-ai-kit/tree/dev

summary: Update default security group in MLkit
description:
Title
Update SageMaker lifecycle configuration script to use user profile security group.

Value Statement
As a BIP AI Tenant who sets up SageMaker environments, I need the ability to use my user profile security group by default in the lifecycle configuration script so that I can simplify environment setup and reduce manual configuration steps.

Acceptance Criteria
When a SageMaker domain is created or updated, the lifecycle configuration script automatically uses the user's profile security group by default.
The script provides clear error messages if the user profile security group is unavailable or misconfigured.
Validation
Test the lifecycle configuration script with various user profiles to confirm it correctly applies the user profile security group.
Verify that error handling and messaging are clear and actionable for tenants.

summary: Update tenant resource bedrock notebooks to use inference profiles
description:

Acceptance Criteria: 
After documenting the inference profile usage, update the tenant resources bed rock notebooks to use inference profiles. Verify that the changes are working in the dev domain and are able to track in usage.

summary: Document inference profiles usage
description:

Acceptance Criteria: 
Create a document on confluence that documents how bedrock is using inference profiles and verify that all the inference profiles are included in the document.

Test the notebook to ensure it works as intended in the dev environment.

summary: Analyze CloudWatch logs and identify relevant metrics for Bedrock model invocations.
description:
Title:
Analyze CloudWatch logs and identify relevant metrics for Bedrock model invocations.

Value Statement:
As an MLOps Engineer, I need to identify metrics in the AWS CloudWatch that are relevant to Bedrock model invocations. The identified metrics will be used to  view recent and historical model usage, offering full transparency and predictability.

* model usage per tenant  (aggregated)
* token usage requests (aggregated)
* price per 1000 input/output tokens?

The goal is to provide accurate and relevant tenant usage of Bedrock model invocations for key operational reports and transparency.

Acceptance Criteria:
Key metrics are identified and validated in order to build a Lambda function to parse the key/value pairs from CloudWatch Bedrock logs.

summary: Enable the access in sbx for guardrails from exec role
description:
Title
Enable access to Bedrock Guardrails from Exec role in a sandbox environment to allow guardrail experimentation

Value Statement
As a BIP AI MLops Engineer, I need the roles to utilize Bedrock Guardrails in a sandbox environment so that I can test guardrails and validate their functionality.

Acceptance Criteria
When requests are made to Bedrock Guardrails, the user has the necessary roles to successfully generate responses. Manually access the Bedrock Guardrail console and configure a test guardrail. Test the guardrail with dummy data in the guardrail testing console to verify successful response.

Assumptions
User has AWS access

Notes
Reach out to infra team to get access provisioned

Out of Scope
Testing guardrail functionality/success. Only need the ability to create guardrails and make guardrail requests without permissions errors.

summary: Investigate if Guardrails has cost track through tags
description:
Title
Investigate whether AWS Bedrock Guardrails offers tagged cost tracking to understand Guardrail cost tracking

Value Statement
As an BIP AI MLOPS Engineer who uses AWS Bedrock Guardrails, I need to investigate guardrail costs and tagging so that I can understand how to track costs incurred by tenants.

Acceptance Criteria
When research is completed, admin users have the ability to get detailed information on guardrails cost tracking with tagging. The existing guardrails confluence document should be updated with this information.

Assumptions
Technical document for AWS Bedrock Guardrails already exists in BIP AI confluence.

summary: Build tenant resources example notebook for basic Bedrock Guardrails functionality
description:
Title
Build tenant resources example notebook to prove functionality of AWS Bedrock Guardrails and outline example usage

Value Statement
As a BIP AI MLOps Engineer who supports secure AI workflows, I need the ability to utilize and provide examples for Bedrock Guardrails so that to ensure PII security and response quality when working with LLMs.

Acceptance Criteria
When a tenant needs to implement Bedrock Guardrails in their workflow, they can refer to the example notebook to streamline the setup process. 
Notebook examples provided for configuration and usage of each guardrail type Include example prompts that pass and fail for each guardrail 
Manually test that notebook examples function as expected for each guardrail

Dependencies
This Story is dependent on the completion of: "Enable access to Bedrock Guardrails from Exec role in a sandbox environment to allow guardrail experimentation" (No ticket number yet)

summary: Design Smoke Test pipeline
description:
As a BIP AI Infra team member who manages the deployment integrity of user-specific environments, I need the ability to automatically trigger a smoke test pipeline whenever a user's domain is changed so that we can ensure core services are functional immediately after updates.

AC:
When a user’s domain is created or modified, the smoke test pipeline is automatically triggered.
When the pipeline is triggered, it should run critical checks 
When all smoke tests pass, the pipeline reports success and logs results to Jenkins and Slack.
When any smoke test fails, the pipeline should halt and notify the engineering team with error details in Slack.
When viewing the pipeline run, it should indicate which domain triggered the execution and timestamp of change.

1) Gateway testing 
2) deploy a domain and have a validation script run

summary: Recreate UI Testing Pipeline for Healthcheck Pipeline
description:
As a BIP AI Infra Engineer who manages platform resiliency and  health, I need to recreate the automated UI testing pipeline that validate the availability, response status, basic functionality of the frontend, integrates into the master health check pipeline, so that we can detect issues early and ensure a stable user experience during deployments or scaling events.

AC

When the UI testing pipeline is triggered, it should send an HTTP request to the platform's frontend URL and verify a 200 response code.
When a timeout or HTTP error is encountered, the pipeline should mark the stage as failed and report the response status in Jenkins logs.
When the pipeline runs successfully, it should confirm UI availability and return a success status.
When the pipeline completes, it should post the result (success or failure) to the Slack pipelines channel.
When needed, the pipeline should support parameterized execution to test against different environments

summary: Update MFE/API apps to fix high vulnerabilities in Fortify scan reports
description:
Value Statement
As a cloud infra engineer who fixes vulnerabilities in BIP AI apps, I need the ability to fix the high+ findings from fortify scan report so that clean fortify report can be generated from BIP AI apps.

Acceptance Criteria
1. Fix high+ vulnerabilities from fortify scan report.
2. Build new image and deploy to sbx.

summary: Store mlmats image in BIA docker registry to correct storage path
description:
Value Statement
As a cloud infra engineer who manages docker image registry, I need the ability to store mlmats images in BIA docker registry so that correct storage path is used.

Acceptance Criteria
1. Use container-registry-bia instead of container-registry-candp for Nexus registry repo name.
2. Update new image paths in IaC templates, charts, value files etc.
3. Determine how to configure Nexus rbac role to write to BIA docker registry only. Announce the plan to team.

summary: Test Crossplane Grafana provider in ephemeral cluster to validate platform compatibility and readiness
description:
As a member of the BIP-AI team developing infrastructure automation, I need to test the Crossplane Grafana provider in an ephemeral cluster so that we can validate its functionality and resource consumption before promoting it to higher environments.

Value Statement This enables us to validate the Grafana provider's functionality and accurately measure its resource requirements in isolation, ensuring we can deploy it safely to production environments with appropriate resource allocation and confident operational behavior.

Background We are implementing Grafana dashboard and panel automation through Crossplane providers. Before deploying this capability to production environments, we need to test the provider in an ephemeral cluster to validate functionality and measure actual resource consumption patterns for proper sizing and resource requests in production deployments.

Acceptance Criteria

Provider Image Availability

Grafana provider image is built and available in DEV ECR
Image is properly tagged and accessible for deployment
Provider image includes all necessary dependencies
Infrastructure as Code Deployment

Create feature branch in bip-tooling-crossplane-providers repository
Deploy Grafana provider to ephemeral cluster using IaC patterns
Provider deploys successfully with appropriate configuration
Provider Functionality Validation

Grafana provider is available and operational in ephemeral cluster
Deploy test Grafana resource (dashboard or panel) to validate functionality
Verify provider can successfully manage Grafana resources end-to-end
Resource Consumption Analysis

Monitor and document provider resource usage patterns
Capture CPU, memory, and network consumption metrics
Generate recommendations for production resource requests and limits
Documentation and Communication

Draft pull request with implementation details and findings
Advertise results to platform-engineering team
Include screenshots of provider pod metrics showing resource utilization during resource deployment
Definition of Done

Grafana provider successfully deployed to ephemeral cluster via IaC
Test Grafana resources deployed and managed successfully by provider
Resource consumption metrics collected and documented
Resource request recommendations prepared for production deployment
Provider functionality validated end-to-end
Pull request drafted and shared with platform-engineering team including screenshots of provider pod metrics during resource deployment operations
Technical Notes

Use existing Crossplane provider deployment patterns from bip-tooling-crossplane-providers
Follow standard ephemeral cluster testing procedures
Implement appropriate monitoring and metrics collection for resource analysis
Document any provider-specific configuration requirements or constraints
Ensure provider cleanup processes work correctly for ephemeral environments
Consider testing both creation and deletion workflows for complete validation
Capture metrics during both idle and active resource management operations

summary: Onboard bip-ai-blue pseudo tenant for end-to-end testing
description:
Title: Onboard bip-ai-blue pseudo tenant for end-to-end testing

Story As a member of the BIP-AI team, I need bip-ai-blue onboarded as a pseudo tenant so that we can test the complete tenant intake process from start to finish using the same workflows as real tenants.

Value Statement This provides a dedicated test tenant in sandbox that follows the exact same onboarding process as production tenants, enabling comprehensive end-to-end testing of our intake workflows and GitOps processes.

Background We need a pseudo tenant that goes through the complete onboarding process to validate our tenant intake workflows. This tenant should be treated exactly like any other tenant from a process perspective but exists solely for testing purposes in the sandbox environment.

Acceptance Criteria

Add bip-ai-blue to bip-tenant-directory

Create tenant entry with appropriate metadata
Follow existing tenant directory patterns and structure
Create GitOps intake for bip-ai-blue

Setup standard tenant onboarding process in sandbox
Follow established GitOps workflow patterns
Configure AiTenantIntake claim values

Update values-sbx.yaml in us-gov-west-1 with new intake configuration
Deploy via bip-ai-claims ArgoCD application
Verify successful resource creation in sandbox
Definition of Done

bip-ai-blue added to bip-tenant-directory
GitOps intake process completed for bip-ai-blue in sandbox
AiTenantIntake claim deployed successfully via ArgoCD
All tenant resources created and functional in sandbox environment
Technical Notes

Use existing tenant patterns for bip-ai-blue configuration
Follow standard naming conventions and resource tagging
Ensure bip-ai-blue resources are clearly identified as test/pseudo tenant
Leverage existing values-sbx.yaml structure for claim configuration

summary: Update mlkit-cli to handle the new Okta/EntraID dual option screen
description:
Value Statement
As a BIP AI tenant user who connects to Mlflow from SageMaker Studio, I need the ability to use an updated mlkit-cli utility to pass through Okta/EntraID dual option screen in OIDC flow so that I can continue to obtain auth cookie file to connect to Mlflow.

Acceptance Criteria
1 `mlkit-cli auth` command passes through Okta/EntraID dual option screen in OIDC flow to return auth cookie file successfully.
2 Test this in sbx.

NEW AC:
3. Allow Okta email user to enter email code.
4. Fix potential bug of using non-existing sbx platform auth service.

summary: Develop crossplane composition to manage adfs mlops role policies to simplify BIP-AI roles permission management
description:
Title: Develop Crossplane composition for ADFS MLOps role policies to simplify management

Story: 
As a member of the BIP-AI team that uses the ADFS MLOps roles for accessing machine learning operations resources, I need a streamlined Crossplane-based solution to manage IAM policies so that policy updates can be deployed consistently across environments without the complexity of CloudFormation management.

Value Statement: 
This eliminates the maintenance overhead of CloudFormation-managed policies, reduces deployment friction, and aligns our ADFS role policy management with our existing Crossplane infrastructure strategy, enabling faster and more reliable policy updates across all environments.

Background: 
Currently, our ADFS MLOps role policies are managed through CloudFormation, creating maintenance complexity and deployment friction. We need to transition these to Crossplane management to align with our infrastructure-as-code strategy. The roles we manage have specific suffixes (-engineers, -leads, -dataops, -admin) and each role requires two policies (-primary and -secondary), totaling 8 policies per environment. The full role names follow the pattern adfs-project-mlops-\{suffix} with corresponding policy names adfs-project-mlops-\{suffix}-\{primary|secondary}.

Acceptance Criteria:

Create Composite Resource Definition (XRD)

Define a new composite resource type for managing ADFS role policies
Follow existing BIP-AI XRD patterns and naming conventions
Support configuration of role suffixes and policy document sources
Enable external policy document references (not inline policy content)
Create Crossplane Composition

Implement composition using Go templating similar to existing compositions
Generate IAM managed policies for all specified role types with primary/secondary variants
Follow BIP-AI naming conventions and resource tagging standards
Support dynamic policy generation based on composition parameters
Policy Management

Manage 8 total policies per environment (4 role suffixes × 2 policy variants each)
Support configurable policy document sources maintained outside the composition
Enable environment-specific policy customization through values configuration
Testing & Integration

Successfully test composition and XRD in long-lived sandbox environment
Validate proper policy creation with correct naming, tagging, and content
Verify integration with existing Crossplane infrastructure patterns

Definition of Done:
Pull request merged with new composition and XRD
Successful deployment and testing in long-lived sandbox environment
All 8 ADFS MLOps policies successfully managed by Crossplane composition
Validation that policies are correctly created, named, and tagged according to BIP standards
Documentation updated with composition details and usage examples

Technical Notes:
Build upon existing composition patterns from sagemaker-domain-role-composition.yaml and foundation-tenant-support-composition.yaml
Deploy via claim configuration using the values repository pattern to decouple changes from releases
Leverage ArgoCD's environment-specific values handling for multi-environment deployment
Use existing BIP-AI helper templates and naming conventions in _helpers.tpl
Follow the standard BIP-AI resource tagging and metadata patterns
Consider policy document storage strategy (S3, ConfigMap, or external references)
Ensure compatibility with existing IAM role attachment mechanisms
No environment config required - handle environment differences through ArgoCD values pattern

summary: Recreate Sagemaker Domain creation pipeline
description:
As a DevOps engineer who manages automated infrastructure health checks, I need to trigger domain creation and readiness checks as part of the master health check pipeline, so that the overall system health validation process is streamlined, automated, and provides timely feedback.

AC

When a user initiates the master health check pipeline, the system automatically creates a domain claim and polls for its readiness.
If domain creation or readiness check fails, the pipeline notifies appropriate stakeholders (e.g., via Slack).
The domain name, claim status, and relevant output are logged and surfaced within the pipeline’s build description.
The domain creation pipeline can be run as a standalone stage or integrated seamlessly into the master health check pipeline.

summary: Validate Nova pro models in preprod
description:

AC:
Tests done in notebook to run inference off Bedrock in preprod and get LLM response.

summary: Create SPA CI/CD pipeline to improve consistency and automation
description:
Title
Create CI/CD pipeline to automate testing and deployment for SPA.

Value Statement
As a BIP AI Tenant (SPA) who needs to streamline model development and deployment workflows, I need the ability to use a CI/CD pipeline that automates unit tests, syntax checks, formatting, and endpoint deployment so that I can ensure code quality and efficiently deploy model endpoints.

Acceptance Criteria
When a user pushes code to the repository, the GitHub Actions pipeline runs unit tests, syntax checks, and formatting validation.
When a model is ready for deployment, the Jenkins pipeline deploys the model endpoint to the specified environment.
Validation:

Verify that the GitHub Actions pipeline successfully executes unit tests, syntax checks, and formatting checks on code push.
Verify that the Jenkins pipeline deploys the model endpoint to the correct environment without errors.

 

Repo is: [https://github.com/department-of-veterans-affairs/bip-spa-sc-death-classifier/tree/main]

 

 

Sample repos to use as template for github action and jenkins pipeline:

 

[https://github.com/department-of-veterans-affairs/bip-ai-pilot-use-case/tree/main/jenkins-workflows]

[https://github.com/department-of-veterans-affairs/bip-tera-memo-automation/tree/dev/jenkins]

[https://github.com/department-of-veterans-affairs/bip-tera-memo-automation/tree/dev/.github/workflows]

summary: 4.3 A - MLE Shadow Service Desk
4.3 B - MLE Shadow Service Desk
Refactoring and abstracting ARIA code to be more reusable
description:
## Overview
Refactor the ARIA API-related code to make it more reusable and easily extensible. The new API structure should allow engineers to easily understand, extend, and configure functionality with minimal code changes.

## Acceptance Criteria
- ARIA API codebase is refactored into reusable modules/components this includes cache, users and logging
- API behavior is easily configurable
- Clear documentation within code for future engineers
- Code is structured to allow easy expansion and extension
- API is fully functional post-refactor

## Value
This enables a more maintainable, understandable, and extensible API that can evolve with future needs and is straightforward for engineers to work with.

description:
As an engineer, I want to assist the deployment of Aria into the gateway so that users have a working Aria chatbot to interact with. 

**Acceptance Criteria:**

summary: Add conversation history to API
description:
As an engineer, I want the API to support saving and retrieving conversation history using Langchain, so that users have the ability to pull up past conversations from Aria.

**Acceptance Criteria:**
- When a user interacts with Aria, the user's conversation is saved persistently using Langchain.
- This enables users to access and review their conversation history.

**Benefit:**
- Users gain continuity and can reference previous interactions with Aria, improving usability and experience.

Acceptance Criteria (A/C):
- Create or find existing automation to migrate Jenkins pipelines from one instance to another.
- For the Stage and Preprod environments, all existing pipelines are migrated to their respective BIP-AI versions.
- For the Dev environment, only migrate the following pipelines:

> Note for TRA's: This list needs to be added to Jira after the team is given more time to identify the pipelines they want to keep in Dev.

summary: Update paramater and secret names with new domain IDs
description:
Title
Update parameter and secret names to include SageMaker domain IDs for IAM policy compliance.

Value Statement
As a BIP AI MLOps Engineer who manages AWS resources, I need the ability to update parameter store and secrets manager names to include SageMaker domain IDs so that they are compliant with IAM policies and ensure proper access control.

Acceptance Criteria
When parameters in AWS Systems Manager Parameter Store are updated, their names include the new SageMaker domain IDs.
When secrets in AWS Secrets Manager are updated, their names include the new SageMaker domain IDs.
The update process ensures no disruption to existing workflows or applications relying on these parameters and secrets.
A script or process is provided to automate the renaming and validation of updated names.
Validation
Verify that all relevant parameters and secrets are updated with the new SageMaker domain IDs.
Test IAM policies to confirm access control works as expected with the updated names.
Ensure applications and workflows using the parameters and secrets continue to function without errors.

summary: QA Test Exam Verification Agent Domain in Dev
description:

AC: Ensure that the dev domain passes the validation script. This AC should require the LCC-attachment pipeline to be run beforehand.

summary: Organize SPA GitHub repository to improve usability.
description:
Title
Organize SPA GitHub repository to improve usability.

Value Statement
As a BIP AI Tenant who works with the SPA GitHub repository, I need the ability to organize and clean up the repository so that it is easier to navigate, maintain, and collaborate effectively.

Acceptance Criteria
When the repository is reviewed, unused or outdated files are identified and removed.
When the repository is organized, files and folders are structured logically based on functionality or purpose.

Validation
Verify that the repository structure is logical and easy to navigate.
Confirm that all outdated or unused files have been removed.
Ensure that the updated documentation accurately reflects the new structure.

summary: Prototype Multi-Model Bedrock Inference Profiles with Crossplane.
description:
Story: Implement Multi-Model Bedrock Inference Profiles in Dev Environment
User Story As a BIP AI Platform Infrastructure Engineer, I want to deploy and validate multi-model Bedrock inference profiles in our dev environment, so that tenants can request access to multiple AI models through a single declarative configuration.

Business Value

Multi-Model Efficiency: Enable tenants to access multiple AI models (Claude, GPT, etc.) through unified inference profiles
Production Readiness: Validate prototype in real dev environment before stage/prod deployment
Tenant Self-Service: Allow tenants to specify which models they need through simple YAML configuration
Cost Control: Implement proper model access controls and tenant-specific model allowlists
Acceptance Criteria

AC1: Multi-Model Configuration

 Deploy composition that creates separate inference profiles per model requested
 Validate tenant model requests against environment-specific allowlists
 Support both single and multi-model requests through bedrockModelsRequested parameter
AC2: Dev Environment Deployment

 Deploy to dev environment with real tenant namespace integration
 Validate against actual environment configs and model lists
 Test with multiple tenants having different model access permissions
AC3: Model Access Validation

 Confirm inference profiles are created only for tenant-allowed models
 Test model invocation through bedrock-runtime API for each created profile
 Validate proper error handling for unauthorized model requests
AC4: Production-Ready Implementation

 Implement proper resource naming conventions (inferenceProfileName-modelShortName)
 Apply complete tagging strategy including tenant-specific tags
 Ensure proper cleanup when tenant model access is revoked
Definition of Done

 Multi-model inference profiles successfully created in dev environment
 All model-specific profiles can be invoked via bedrock-runtime API
 Tenant isolation and model access controls verified
 Resource lifecycle tested (create, update, delete scenarios)
 Ready for stage environment promotion

summary: Finish incorporating MFA for MLFlow in tenant_resources repo
description:
Value Statement: As a BIP AI MLOps Engineer who supports tenant workflows, I need to update tenant resources so that tenants can securely access and use their MLflow instances without disruptions

Acceptance Criteria: Updates are made to the tenant resources repo and domain validation script to meet new authentication requirements. Validate that tenants can successfully authenticate and access their MLflow instances after the updates. Provide documentation of the changes made and any necessary steps for tenants to adapt to the updated authentication process

summary: Create Jenkins pipeline to enable LCC script attachment to all staging domains
description:
Initiative: As a BIP AI MLOps developer, I need to create a Jenkins pipeline to attach LCC scripts to staging domains so that when users start a JupyterLab space their environments are configured correctly for development. There are already Jenkins pipelines in dev and preprod to attach LCC scripts, and these pipelines need to be replicated for stage. This ticket is created based on tenant request from https://jira.devops.va.gov/browse/BIPAIS-135.


AC:
Jenkins pipeline to attach LCC to stage domains is created.
Jenkins pipeline is run against all (8) stage domains and validated.

summary: Research MLFlow authentication flow to integrate with Entra
description:
Value Statement
As a cloud infra engineer who manages authentication mechanism in MLflow tooling, I need the ability to research Entra authentication flow so that a solution is recommended for tenant to log in MLFlow using Entra post Okta migration.

Acceptance Criteria
1. Write a document to describe the current MLflow login flow with Okta, the changes EntraID brings, and a recommended solution for MLflow to work with EntraID.

summary: Provision Exam Verification Agent Domain in Dev
description:
As a BIP AI Infra Engineer I need to provision the Exam Verification Agent Domain in Dev so that the Exam Verification Team can access Sagemaker Studio to access AI resources.
A/C:
 - A new AI Intake object is added to the bip-ml-mats-infrastructure-values repo for the Exam Verification Agent in the us-gov-west-1/values-dev.yaml.
 - The new domain appears in the AI Gateway and Sagemaker Studio is accessible [https://ai|https://ai/].dev.bip.va.gov

summary: Hold Technical Requirements Review for Exam Verification Agent
description:
As a BIP AI Team Member I need to schedule and hold the Technical Requirements Review for Exam Verification Agent so that their use case and timeline can be approved and we can proceed to provisioning their environment.
 - A meeting is schedule with the Exam Verification Agent and BIP AI teams.
 - The Technical Requirements Document for Exam Verification Agent is reviewed by all attendees.

summary: Create Access control system in the BIP AI Gateway to conditionally give users access to features based on RBAC Roles
description:
Value Statement:

As an infrastructure engineer, I need to implement an access control system in the BIP AI Gateway to enable conditional feature visibility for users based on their RBAC group memberships.

A/C
- The BIP Gateway must conditionally grant users access to UI routes, micro frontends, alerts, and microservices according to access control rules defined by their RBAC groups.
- Access permissions are enforced consistently across all relevant components.
- The system supports dynamic updates to RBAC group memberships and access rules.
- Proper logging and auditing are in place for access control decisions.
- Comprehensive documentation is provided for configuring and managing access control.
